title: Interview: U.S., China "together can do so much," says British business leader
content:
LONDON, Feb. 2 (Xinhua) -- The United States and China, as two biggest economic powers in the world, can accomplish plenty together but will stumble when apart, chairman of Britain's 48 Group Club Stephen Perry, has said.
"This period of history is different, and the risks of cooperative action failing will cause much more global distress," warned Perry in a recent interview with Xinhua.
Perry, whose father "icebreaker" Jack Perry helped establish one of the first modern-day trade links between China and the outside world during the Cold War, highlighted the need for leaders to "build a new world which eradicates poverty and lifts all."
He noted that the world is witnessing rapid change with the pandemic and an economic recession. "The markets need guiding, the future needs guiding. We are no longer in the past when ships would sail through new seas," he said.
"The world now has (over) 7 billion people who need food, clothes, health, jobs and enjoyment, and a world which needs safeguarding and safety from crime," Perry added.
Believing that international bodies, such as the United Nations and World Trade Organization, are all part of the journey of change to a safer and prosperous world, Perry added that "they need the cooperation and unity of steps from the two major trading nations of the world -- the USA and China."
"Together these two nations can provide a leadership and vision," he said.
Noting that the international community has an opportunity currently to find common ground and ways forward, he said countries around the world also need to "help the markets and commercial companies prosper and invest in better ways for the commercial world to help develop the world."
"This is not a time for any country to be first," he said, "This is a time for all countries to cooperate and create real progress for humanity."
Perry said the world is set for dramatic change over the next 100 years, "beyond anything that can now be imagined."
"We can build the future together or conflict and disease can take too big a place," Perry argued.
The United States and China must work together to build a better world instead of adopting a winner-takes-all approach, Perry said. "If there is a winner then there will be much loss." Enditem
